problem: I have twenty balls numbered 1 through 20 in a bin.  In how many ways can I select 2 balls, if the order in which I draw them doesn't matter?
solution: If the order the balls are selected matters, there are 20 choices for the first selection and 19 choices for the second selection.  However, $20\cdot 19$ counts each pair of balls twice, once for each possible order in which they can be selected.  So, we must divide by $2$, , to get $\dfrac{20 \times 19}{2} = \boxed{190}$.
